questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a sudden onset of fatigue, jaundice, and dark urine. On examination, she has splenomegaly. Laboratory tests reveal an elevated reticulocyte count, elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and positive direct Coombs test for IgG antibodies. Which of the following is the most appropriate first-line treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Management of Warm Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia

First-Line Treatment:

  • Initiate treatment with prednisone at 1 mg/kg/day, which induces remission in approximately 50% of cases.
  • Combine with anti-CD20 Rituximab (100 mg/week for 4 weeks) to potentially reduce relapse rates. (Option C)

Alternative Therapies for Relapse/Refractoriness:

  • Splenectomy can improve anemia and decrease reliance on other therapies by eliminating a primary site of hemolysis, but it also poses risks of sepsis and thrombosis. (Option A ruled out)
  • Second- and Third-Line Treatments: Azathioprine (Option B ruled out), Cyclophosphamide, Cyclosporine, Mycophenolate, Intravenous immunoglobulin (Option D ruled out)

Additional Support:

  • Erythropoietin may be used to help reduce or avoid the need for red blood cell transfusions in cases of severe anemia associated with reticulocytopenia.

Management of Cold Agglutinin Disease (CAD)

First-Line Treatment:

  • Rituximab is the primary treatment for CAD, as prednisone and splenectomy are ineffective in managing this condition.

Emerging Therapies:

  • For relapses, consider B-cell receptor inhibitors such as venetoclax & ibrutinib, as well as the proteasome inhibitor bortezomib.

Supportive Care:

  • Blood transfusions may be beneficial, though donor red cells (I-positive) will have a similar survival rate to the patient’s own cells.
  • It is essential to keep both the blood bag and the patient's extremities warm during transfusions.

A 70-year-old man with hypertension is prescribed α-methyldopa. After a few months of therapy, he develops mild anemia. His DAT is positive for IgG, and the eluate shows panagglutination. There is no evidence of renal dysfunction or hemoglobinuria. What is the most likely cause of his anemia?
questions.explanation:
Drug-immune hemolytic anemia

Category

Mechanism

Clinical Presentation

Example Drugs

Drug Adsorption (Penicillin Type) (Option A)

IgG antibodies bind to drug-coated RBCs leading to phagocytosis by splenic macrophages

Gradual hemolysis over 7-10 days; splenic sequestration
  • Penicillin
  • Cephalosporin
  • Tetracycline
  • Tolbutamide

Neoantigen/Immune Complex (Quinidine Type) (Option B)

Antibodies bind to newly formed antigenic sites on RBCs, complement fixation leads to intravascular hemolysis

Acute, severe hemolysis; hemoglobinuria; renal failure
  • Quinidine
  • Stibophen
  • Sulfonamides
  • Rifampicin

Autoimmune Mechanism (α-Methyldopa Type) (Option C)

Polyclonal IgG autoantibodies attack RBC membrane components.

Chronic, mild hemolysis; similar to idiopathic warm AIHA
  • α-methyldopa
  • Cladribine
  • Fludarabine
  • Mefenamic acid
  • Procainamide

Non-Immunologic Protein Adsorption (Option D)

Proteins like fibrinogen, complement, or albumin adsorb to RBC membranes, not associated with RBC destruction

Positive DAT; no hemolysis
  • Cephalosporin
  • Cisplatin
  • Oxaliplatin

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman with a history of rheumatoid arthritis presents with fatigue, pallor, and splenomegaly. Laboratory evaluation reveals anemia and a positive direct Coombs test. The DAT shows agglutination with both anti-IgG and anti-C3 reagents. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with her presentation?

options.label: C
options.text: Hapten type drug-induced immune hemolytic anemia

questions.explanation:
Major Patterns of Direct Antiglobulin Reaction

Reaction Pattern

Type of Immune Injury

IgG Alone
  • Warm-antibody autoimmune hemolytic anemia.
  • Drug-immune hemolytic anemia: hapten drug adsorption type or autoantibody type. (Option C)

Complement Alone
  • Cold-agglutinin disease. (Option A)
  • Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria. (Option D)
  • Drug-immune hemolytic anemia: ternary complex type.
  • Warm-antibody AHA with subthreshold IgG deposition.

IgG Plus Complement
  • Warm-antibody AHA. (Option B)
  • Drug-immune hemolytic anemia: autoantibody type (rare)

Laboratory Features of Immune-Mediated Hemolytic Anemia (AIHA)

Parameter

Key Features

Hemoglobin & Hematocrit

Ranges from normal (compensated hemolysis) to extremely low (severe RBC destruction)

Elevated MCV.

Reticulocyte Counts

Typically elevated.

May be low early due to marrow shutdown, infection, or parvovirus B19; hyperplastic marrow.

Peripheral Blood Smear

Shows:

  • Reticulocytosis
  • Polychromatophilia (white arrow)
  • Macrocytosis (red arrow)
  • Nucleated RBCs
  • Spherocytes (black arrow)
  • Agglutination
  • Erythrophagocytosis.

WBC & Platelet Counts
  • WBCs may be elevated or low.
  • Thrombocytopenia suggests Evans syndrome; possible immune-mediated cytopenias.

Serum Tests
  • Elevated unconjugated bilirubin (<5 mg/dL)
  • Hemoglobinemia, hemoglobinuria.
  • Low haptoglobin, increased urobilinogen, increased LDH.
  • Possible false-positive syphilis tests.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with complaints of acrocyanosis and fatigue. She has a history of multiple myeloma and has been on lenalidomide therapy for the past 3 months. Laboratory tests reveal a hemoglobin level of 10.5 g/dL, a reticulocyte count of 5%, and a positive direct Coombs test. What is the most likely antibody type involved in this patient’s condition?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Warm AIHA (WAIHA)

Cold AIHA (CAD)

Type of Antibody

Primarily IgG (Option A)

Primarily IgM (Option B)

Optimal Temperature

37°C

4°C–30°C

Onset

Abrupt and dramatic

Gradual and chronic

Etiology

Idiopathic

Secondary causes:

  • Autoimmune diseases (e.g., SLE, scleroderma, RA)
  • Infections:
  • Parvovirus B19, HIV, HCV, viral vaccines)
  • Babesia
  • Lymphoproliferative disorders (e.g., CLL, multiple myeloma)
  • Chronic inflammatory disorders (e.g., IBD, thyroiditis including Hashimoto)
  • Drug-induced cases (e.g., cefotetan, ceftriaxone, piperacillin, methyldopa, fludarabine)

Idiopathic

Secondary causes:

  • Infections:
  • (e.g., EBV, CMV)
  • Mycoplasma
  • Waldenströms disease
  • lymphoma
  • Drug-induced cases (e.g., lenalidomide)

Clinical features
  • Abrupt symptoms, potentially severe anemia.
  • Jaundice, splenomegaly.
  • Elevated reticulocyte count, LDH
  • Gradual onset
  • Symptoms worsen with cold exposure.
  • Hemoglobinuria.
  • Acrocyanosis.

Mechanism of Hemolysis
  • The Fc portion of the IgG antibody bound to red cells is recognized by macrophage Fc receptors.
  • Leading to erythrophagocytosis primarily in the spleen, liver, and bone marrow in an extravascular manner.
  • IgM bound to red blood cells activates the complement cascade, leading to intravascular hemolysis, which can result in hemoglobinuria.
  • Activated complement components, such as C3b, opsonize red blood cells, which are then destroyed by macrophages in an extravascular manner.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with hemoglobinuria and abdominal pain after playing outside in cold weather. He had a recent upper respiratory tract infection. Lab findings reveal hemoglobin of 4.2 g/dL, elevated LDH, and positive Donath-Landsteiner test. What is the pathophysiological mechanism of his condition?

options.label: A
options.text: IgG autoantibodies causing RBC lysis at warm temperatures

options.label: B
options.text: IgM autoantibodies causing RBC agglutination at cold temperatures

options.label: C
options.text: IgG auto-antibodies binding to RBCs at cold temperatures and causing lysis upon warming

options.label: D
options.text: Complement-mediated destruction of RBCs without any antibody involvement

questions.correct_answer: C. IgG auto-antibodies binding to RBCs at cold temperatures and causing lysis upon warming
questions.explanation:
Paroxysmal Cold Hemoglobinuria (PCH)

D-L Antibody Characteristics
  • A hemolysin that binds to red blood cells (RBCs) at cold temperatures, fixing complement, and causes lysis when warmed.
  • Typically IgG, directed against the P antigen on RBCs (a glycosphingolipid).
  • "Biphasic" hemolysin: binds at 0°C–4°C and causes lysis when warmed to 37°C.

Clinical Manifestations
  • Sudden onset of fever, back/leg pain, and dark red-to-black hemoglobinuria after cold exposure.
  • Symptoms may include cold-induced urticaria, Raynaud phenomenon, cyanosis, and, rarely, gangrene.
  • Affects mostly children following viral infections (e.g., Mycoplasma, measles, mumps, influenza, EBV, varicella, parvo B19 etc.).
  • Chronic PCH is common in late-stage or congenital syphilis, now rare due to syphilis treatment.

Laboratory Features
  • Severe intravascular hemolysis: hemoglobin <5 g/dL, hemoglobinuria, elevated LDH and bilirubin.
  • Diagnostic hallmark: positive Donath-Landsteiner test
    • It is an in-vitro test that detects anti-P antibodies in a patient's serum by incubating it with red blood cells at low temperatures, causing hemolysis upon warming if the antibodies are present.
  • Direct Antiglobulin Test (DAT) is usually positive for complement (C3) but not IgG.

Management
  • Supportive care: Transfusion of warmed blood if necessary.
  • Steroids: Sometimes used in severe cases (though benefits are unproven).
  • Avoidance of cold exposure: Crucial for chronic cases.
  • Transfusion considerations: No need to search for rare P-negative blood units; standard P-positive blood is generally safe.

questions.explanation:
Feature

Extravascular Hemolysis

Intravascular Hemolysis

Site of Hemolysis

Occurs in the spleen, liver, and reticuloendothelial system.

Occurs within the blood vessels.

Mechanism

Destruction of RBCs by macrophages (phagocytosis).

RBCs lyse due to mechanical injury, complement activation, or toxins.

Serum Haptoglobin

Decreased or slightly reduced.

Significantly decreased or absent.

Hemoglobinemia

Absent.

Present due to free hemoglobin in plasma.

Hemoglobinuria

Absent.

Present (causes dark-colored urine).

Urine Hemosiderin

Absent.

Present (due to renal tubular uptake of hemoglobin).

LDH Levels

Mildly increased.

Markedly increased.

Unconjugated Bilirubin

Elevated (due to breakdown of heme in macrophages).

Elevated (from released heme).

Peripheral Blood Smear

Spherocytes or target cells may be seen.

Schistocytes (fragmented RBCs) are typical.

Reticulocyte Count

Increased.

Increased (if bone marrow compensates).

Associated Conditions

Hereditary spherocytosis, autoimmune hemolytic anemia (warm type).

Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria, mechanical hemolysis (e.g., prosthetic valves), cold AIHA, G6PD deficiency.

Splenomegaly

Common (due to increased RBC destruction).

Rare.

Other features

- Coombs test is positive in autoimmune hemolysis.

- Splenectomy may be beneficial in some cases.

- Hemosiderinuria indicates chronic intravascular hemolysis.

- Schistocytes are a hallmark of microangiopathic hemolysis.

questions.explanation:
Sickle Cell Trait

Sickle Cell Disease

Genetic Profile

One copy of the hemoglobin S gene

Two copies of the hemoglobin S gene (Option A)

Hemoglobin electrophoresis

HbA, HbS present

HbS, HbF, HbA2 present.

HbA absent. (Option C)

Symptoms

Usually asymptomatic

Broad clinical manifestations (eg, generalized pain and fatigue) due to vaso-occlusive crisis, hemolysis, and infectious exacerbations. (Option B)

Onset of symptoms

Exposure to conditions that favor sickling, including:

  • Severe hypoxia
  • Dehydration
  • Increased sympathetic outflow
  • Hypothermia
  • Hyperthermia
  • High 2,3-DPG levels
  • Release of inflammatory cells.
